quoteFirst: He ascends, puts forward the hands of the clock, but forgets to put the hands and the striking bell in harmony. He rumples up the bed, but he does it awkwardly--and it is impossible to reconcile these three facts, the bed crumpled, the clock showing
quoteLast: , and the countess dressed as if it were mid-day. He adds as much as he can to the disorder of the room. He smears a sheet with blood; also the bed-curtains and furniture.

quoteFirst: “There!” said Penrod, returning from performing this errand for the fourth time. “It's
quoteLast: , and I'm not goin' in to look at that ole clock again if I haf to die for it! I never heard anybody make such a fuss in my life, and I'm gettin' tired of it. Must think we want to be all night fixin' this cage for our panther! If you ask me to go and see what time it is again, Herman, I'm a-goin' to take back about askin' mamma at five o'clock, and THEN where'll you be?”
title: Penrod and Sam
author: Tarkington, Booth, 1869-1946

quoteFirst: "As a result of this order, the bombardment of the Turkish left was resumed, the British guns and howitzers lending their aid to the French Artillery as in the previous attacks. At about 6 p.m., a fine attack was launched, 600 yards of Turkish first line trenches were taken, and despite heavy counter-attacks during the night, especially at
quoteLast: , all captured positions are still in our hands. Am afraid casualties are considerable, but details are lacking. The enemy lost very heavily.
title: Gallipoli Diary,  Volume 1
author: Hamilton, Ian, 1853-1947

quoteFirst: They were exceedingly noisy and merry: they seemed to make the arena-side to flash with their teeth. Until about
quoteLast: , many of them shouted insults at the two whites, who sat unmoved, not knowing the debased dialect of the Occidental. quoteFirst: FRIEND STILL:--I suppose ere this you have seen those five large and three small packages I sent by way of Reading, consisting of three men and women and children. They arrived here this morning at 8-1/2 o'clock and left
quoteLast: . You will please send me any information likely to prove interesting in relation to them.
title:
The Underground Railroad
A Record of Facts, Authentic Narratives, Letters, &c., Narrating the Hardships, Hair-Breadth Escapes and Death Struggles of the Slaves in Their Efforts for Freedom, As Related by Themselves and Others, or Witnessed by the Author.

quoteLast: ; the _New York_ was badly damaged; no lives lost.

quoteFirst: The Nottingham roughs, who were in great force, made an invasion, and drove all back who would not buy Nottingham tickets. Spring, who had provided tickets for the London men, had not yet arrived. At
quoteLast: the men entered the ring――Caunt first, attended by Molyneux the Black and Jem Turner as seconds, Butler having charge of the bottles. Bendigo was attended by Nick Ward and Jack Hannan, Jem Ward and Jem Burn. They shook hands, and tossed for choice of corners.

quoteLast: , having arrived there at a quarter before three. The kindness and attention to us of Lord and of Lady Breadalbane (who is very delicate) were unbounded.

quoteFirst: Though we used to call Mountstephen Molly, he didn't look a bit like a Molly now, for he walked the deck as calm and composed as if nothing particular was going to happen.  I asked him what o'clock it was.  He said, `
quoteLast: .'  Just then the _Dreadnought_ opened her fire on the French commodore; and didn't Captain Suckling pound him--knocking away in a few minutes several of his spars, and so wounding his rigging that he fell on board the _Greenwich_, which, as I said, was close astern of him.
title: The Missing Ship: The Log of the "Ouzel" Galley
